prompt: Outline the logical approach a civil engineer would take to plan the construction of a pedestrian bridge over a small river. Discuss site analysis, assumptions, structural design, material selection, calculations for load-bearing capacity, and presentation of the design.

criteria.name: Site Assessment and Assumptions
criteria.description: Explains how site conditions are evaluated and the assumptions made for planning.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Comprehensively explains site factors (e.g., soil, terrain) and justifies assumptions.
performance_descriptors.good: Explains key site conditions and lists assumptions clearly.
performance_descriptors.average: Covers general site conditions with some assumptions.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Mentions site conditions briefly; assumptions vague.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to assess the site or state assumptions.

criteria.name: Structural Design and Material Selection
criteria.description: Describes structural planning with rational material choices for environmental and load needs.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Detailed and justified design choices with proper materials for use case.
performance_descriptors.good: Sound design with appropriate materials mentioned.
performance_descriptors.average: General design approach with minimal justification.
performance_descriptors.poor: No meaningful structural plan or material discussion.

criteria.name: Load Calculations and Engineering Analysis
criteria.description: Uses appropriate methods to estimate bridge loads and capacity.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Performs relevant calculations with clear method and logic.
performance_descriptors.good: Performs basic calculations with minor gaps.
performance_descriptors.average: Attempts basic load estimation with limited accuracy.
performance_descriptors.poor: No engineering analysis or relevant formulas used.

criteria.name: Design Communication and Reporting
criteria.description: Presents bridge design with diagrams, plan views, or technical notes.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Well-documented design using visuals, measurements, and technical commentary.
performance_descriptors.good: Diagram and explanation present with minor omissions.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Basic description with unclear or missing visuals.
performance_descriptors.poor: No structured communication of the design.

llm_questions: How do civil engineers assess a site for a pedestrian bridge?
What materials are best for short-span pedestrian bridges?
How is load capacity calculated for small bridges?
What are common structural layouts for pedestrian crossings?
How should bridge designs be presented for approval?
llm_answers: They evaluate soil type, topography, and water levels to understand foundation needs.
Steel and reinforced concrete are common for durability and strength.
Loads are calculated using codes (e.g., pedestrian density) and safety factors.
Beam, truss, or arch designs are common depending on span and support.
Designs are shown with plan views, cross-sections, and structural notes.
